instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01949: What is 820-01949? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1v
threads.message:
Hi I'm a new poster to the forum. Have been reading for a while now. But this is my first post so excuse me if not good.

Got a liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Was already been played with. Found a <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> on the board in stead of a <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP>. Replaced it off course with a new ISL 9240. But still no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. What is needed for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to create <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

Please advice where to look. 

Measurements:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3,3V

USB-C 5V 0,049A.

Thanks in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1v
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
If good, post basic <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1v
threads.message:
Hi 2infrmaticos,

Thxs for fast reply: 
Diode mode in <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.458 measured at f7000 pin 2 (Red pin on ground)

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages: 
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> 5,1V
AUX-DET 1,28
VDDA 5,05
VVDP 5,05
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> (looks like nc, if you mean pin 28 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?)
Amon 0V
Bmon 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1v
threads.message:
Check all <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> surrounding components; pay atention to Q/R/<CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR>/40 and their traces.

Be sure to have good solders and traces.
Try known good <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1v
threads.message:
Yesss, it was the <TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR>. Replaced it from a donor board and it works perfectly!!

thxs 2Informaticos
